4.5 stars.  If you want an affordable tablet to watch YouTube videos or netflix, surf online for news or use in the kitchen when referring to recipes/ use as a PDF/ebook reader, look no further. This nifty cheap tablet delivers. No, it does not have retina display, so watching a movie with a buddy is not ideal (although this is very helpful if you have a nosy airplane seat mate). I doubt that the speakers, while serviceable, would blow anyone away. The camera (both back and front) is nothing to write home about either--useful  so the other party can see you when skyping or using viber, but that's pretty much it.

Why 4.5 stars?  Because the tablet is responsive, user friendly, relatively sturdy, ships with a screen protector (definitely a must for me), PLUS has Bluetooth (just BT your spotify to your stereo), a mini hdmi connector, AND the option for cheap expandable memory (ha! Take THAT iPad!). And did I mention it is cheap? For the price you can buy another one for your buddy to use, plus memory, and it would still be cheaper than a comparably sized second hand ipad. Battery life is acceptable: with medium usage (random web searches, a few games of agent Alice, and around 2 hours of nonstop ebook reading, I was left with maybe 40% power.

 I took away half a star because
- it occasionally (rare but it happens) freezes on me, but it is nothing that a reboot wouldn't fix
- the wall charger cable feels flimsy. I've been using my tablet for two months now and it is still fine, but I can see possibly needing to replace it later this year.

Overall, this tablet is a great, inexpensive option for the casual tablet user. If your needs are similar to mine, I definitely recommend getting it.

The screen is not as sensitive as my last tablet. Frequently it will not respond to commands, it takes several attempts before it accepts what I am trying to do. After reading the ( pathetically small) user "manual" and going thru all the settings options we can not locate a screen calibration option.
It does have a focus setting for the camera which is nice, the sound is ok for a tablet, the graphics are good, and the internet connectivity is better than the other tablets we have in the home.  All of these are great, but still not much good if we can't get the screen calibrated to the user.

Received this tablet pretty fast, working with it for a while noticed a few things, first of all the sound for typing on it's virtual keys was very loud and annoying, so I ended up turning key sounds off completely, also when using google voice search the initial sound it makes before you talk into the microphone is super high pitched, loud and off-putting, pretty much have to set the volume either to mute or one level above mute before using google voice search feature. Another thing, on the home screen when viewing tablet horizontally, the labels underneath the icons disappear, so if you don't know what the icon stands for, you have to rotate the tablet vertically, this way the labels under icons appear, using an alternative launcher can fix this issue but additional launcher would use extra ram. I also noticed, my old 7" inch "Azpen 727 tablet"  had two volume keys on the task bar (left and right from home button) always visible so it was super easy to control volume, this tablet doesn't have them, another feature that my 7" Azpen has and this one doesn't is flash player build right into it's stock web browser so you could watch streaming videos right from it's web browser. The viewing angles are just like with any other cheap tablet, best if looked at directly. In radio mode, there is no way to control the volume, you can see the volume line go up and down but it doesn't actually change volume, default volume level for radio is pretty loud, if you are a fan of listening to the radio, you could purchase special headphones with physical volume switch.
The thing I did like about this tablet is it that came with pre-installed protective film on front and back and the boot time when powering it on is pretty fast. I've also noticed that when plugging it into charger, i didn't have to initially charge it for 10 hours, the unit was completely charged in under 1 hour because the battery was already at over 80%.

This is a good tablet for the price. But don't bother purchasing the SmartGuard protection and read your manufacture warranty carefully. SmartGuard is worthless protection and the warranty from the manufacturer has a very short duration, so you really don't have much protection if something breaks on this tablet. It's less risk to purchase a tablet from a well-known manufacturer like Amazon, because they will work with you if something happens to your device. Don't waste what little money you're about to spend.

After weeks of looking through reviews online, I decided that this tablet would suit my needs as a college student.  It arrived right on time and well packaged.  When I opened the box I was a little disappointed by the build of the device. It doesn't feel sturdy and feels like it could shatter if even slightly mishandled.  The screen looks more like plastic than glass.  I've only had this product for 24 hours so this is my initial impression.
Is it worth the money?  Somewhat.  While it feels like a flimsy product, it performs quite well.  It handles apps with no problems and plays games just fine.  I have had no WiFi connectivity issues and though I have only 3-4 apps installed, it hasn't frozen on me (yet).
That brings me to the biggest let down of this tablet.  The screen.  It has one of the worst screens I've seen on any device (even compared to lcd panels from 20 years ago).  Viewing the tablet head on, it looks like you're staring at a fuzzy hologram of sorts.  It hurts to read any text, and images are distorted.  The upper half of the screen looks whitewashed, and the bottom half is a negative image.  Now if you tilt the screen upwards at an odd angle, it alleviates some of this, but still isn't very clear.  I've found that looking at the tablet upside down (with the auto-rotation turned on), helps a little bit but doesn't fix the problem.  However in portrait mode, forget about it.  The tablet is essentially unusable when held vertically.  Everything looks terribly distorted, and I get a headache after 2 seconds of trying to look at something.
This is my first off-brand 10.1 inch tablet, so I'm not sure if the screens are supposed to be this bad.  I previously owned a cheap 7" tab that had a much better screen, but only lasted a year before it quit.
At this point in time I don't plan on returning the tablet, because for my purposes (quick emails and Google searches) it looks bearable.  However if I was a daily user and wanted to watch videos, play games, and surf the web, I would've returned it.

I don't usually write reviews, but I'm making an exception for an exceptionally good tablet.  I'm not a gamer, so I can't speak about the Dragon Touch A1X Plus for that.  I'm on the road with clients a lot and for that I need a tablet that's:  durable, fast (enough) for communications, able to handle business documents -- correspondence, narrative reports, spreadsheets, etc -- Bluetooth enabled and wouldn't cost a fortune.  AND -- and for me this is the biggie -- would allow me to plug in an external drive, such as a thumb drive, so I could have my client files at hand.  This little baby does that -- all of that -- at a price within almost anyone's reach.  Yes, I know that the Surface also lets you plug in an external drive, and yes it comes with the whole Microsoft Office suite. In fact my wife has one.  But it's balky and you have to put up with Microsoft's annoying, infuriating auto-updates when it wants, not when you do!  And it's way more expensive!

The Dragon Touch is Android based and you have access to a huge array of downloadable -- and often free -- productivity software, so I don't miss the Microsoft products at all.  Plus the Dragon Touch is expandable.

So, why not 5 stars?  For me, a couple reasons:  The screen could be a little sharper.  And I wish it would have two things the Surface has:  that neat little stand built into the back, and that detachable keyboard that also protects the screen -- just not the one the Surface uses which is crummy.  None of those is a big deal though and don't detract from the excellent qualities of the Dragon Touch!

Worth the money for a value tablet.  Screen resolution not the best.  Screen can be a little hard to see sometimes, it needs a certain viewing angle.  Apparently the WiFi receiver is in the bottom of the tablet.  I kept loosing connection and getting poor reception.  Downloaded an internet speed test and ran the test holding the tablet in all four directions from the exact same spot in my home.  Connection is best with the unit flipped upside down.  This will have your power button on the bottom left as you view the screen.  Wierd but it solved the problem.  ZERO lost connections or poor Wifi now that I use this as my default viewing position.
The tablet is amazing except for the battery life. I'll be playing a game and it'll be at maybe 70% battery and last another 30 min to an hour.

I am very impressed.  This tablet is sturdy, quick, and lightweight.  The screen is HD, very sharp and clear. Although short of state of the art, the screen is more than acceptable.

I only use basic functions of cameras, and the photos I took were sharp and clear.

Charge battery for a full 10 hours before using!  "Extra long battery life" is highly rated by external sites, It obviously depends on how you are using it.  Movies and gaming drain a battery much faster than internet browsing or offline work.  I listened to an audiobook for 10 hours and the battery indicator is still about 30% full.

I upgraded the tablet using an Ultra 64 GB MICRO SD XCI card in the side port labeled "TF card" (See storage in settings.)  The card required simple reformatting .  Initially the card was not recognized. I pulled additional information by swiping down on the top left corner of the tablet revealing more information and easily completed the reformatting.  Knowledge of an android platform will be helpful.

The screen is very responsive to a finger touch.  When using a stylus, use gentle pressure.  Even moderate pressure will cause the keyboard to display the alternative keyboard stroke.  For instance, pressing an "o" too firmly will display a "9".  I discovered this accidentally after some frustration.  Once I developed the proper pressure or just used my fingers, the screen touch performed very well.

I also bought the Tabsuit PU leather keyboard case.  Fits and works very well.  The strap does not have a strong enough magnet to hold it closed, (which is appropriate due to proximity to tablet), a different type of fastener such as velcro would have been better.  It closes like a book and is very acceptable to me, especially for the price.

There is a slight flaw in the top corner of the tablet's screen; but it does not interfer with viewing, and not worth exchanging.  I'm still having problems with the voice to text function, but it may be operator error.  I'll update this when I figure it out.

I gave this product 5 stars because it far exceeded my expectations for the price, especially with a very inexpensive memory upgrade to an additional 64 GB.  I have casually used several friends much more expensive tablets, and the Dragon Touch A1X competes very favorably.

I completely went out on a limb buying the refurbished Dragon Touch A1X Plus... My son hijacked my other tablet so I decided to get myself a new one and give him his own for his games and videos. The tablets condition was like new. No scratches.. No types of marks or smudges either. One thing that I'm worried about is the back feels very smooth I have a bit of a fear it may fly out of my hand if I'm not careful with it. Otherwise the build is nice. It feels like it was put together nicely. The screen is a bit tricky. I would have given it a 5 star rating but viewing it at certain angles gives the screen a negative appearance. There are some things I really love about this unit.... You can use videos as your wallpaper! It has an HDMI port, micro SD card slot for expansion up to 64gb, the sound quality is very good and quite loud for a budget tablet, also the battery life seems long lasting. I turned it on at about 8:30PM, downloaded a bunch of apps, played a few games and it's only down to 76% 3 and a half hours later. That's pretty darn good considering the brightness is all the way up and WiFi is on. The battery life on this unit is fantastic. I definitely recommend purchasing this particular unit if you're looking for a tablet to purchase. I'll be uploading a video to go with this review here on Amazon tomorrow.

Lets address the elephant in the room, the 4 star(would give it a 4.5). It is very smooth, and can cause the tablet to slip out of your hands. Even my rough fingers had trouble gripping it. Make sure to get a great case, best bet is a shield case or something to protect it from spills, and drops.
4.4.2 KITKAT is the main culprit. This version no longer allows you to saves apps, and games to the SD card, even some of my pictures, and videos wouldn't load from the SD card. These are the two biggest cons.

GAMES & APPS: This tablet played all the free games at peak performance. The exception to this rule are MMO's where server load will dictate your experience, and the 1GB ram will have trouble keeping the game smooth. May have to lower the graphics on some other games as well. Other then that, the apps worked great, you name it it loaded it.

ISSUES WITH CERTAIN GAMES AND APPS: The game Kritika seems to have graphic issues, and can cause the tablet to crash and reset. AVAST caused my tablet to experience instability issues, with random reboots,and freezing(CM SECURITY IS RECOMMENDED).

NO BLOATWARE: This tablet comes with all the necessary android bells and whistles, but what you will not find here is 50 + apps preinstalled that no one uses. No more deleting 5 dating apps, and other sponsorware. This makes sure you have optimal room for things you actually want on your tablet.

DESIGN: This is a big tablet standing at 10.1 inches this is big. The border around the screen is almost an inch so the screen looks smaller when compared to the specs. The overall look is very sleek, and stylish. Budget tabs tend to stand out like a sore thumb.  With performance and looks you can feel proud of saying that most people OVERPAID for their tablets.

VERY SENSITIVE: make sure you have a great case to protect the back, as even the slightest touch can cause your fingers to bleed through the back and show up on the screen. This can potentially damage your tablet, so invest in a a case. DO NOT take this lightly.

VIDEO & SOUND: Movies, and TV sound great, the tablet is loud enough to hear without the background music and S.E. from drowning out the movie. That said music is hard to enjoy from the base speaker, so grab some speakers,or headset and you are good. The image quality is god enough, but do not expect true HD picture with stunning color, this is a budget tablet, and the slightest tilt can make the entire picture dark. Best viewed if looking straight at it. This can technically be considered a plus, and it can stop people from eves dropping on your activities.

BLUETOOTH: great for wireless speakers to really enjoy the moment where ever you are

It saddens me that I have to leave a bad review for this tablet. I had high hopes after reading many reviews and seeing the 4 star rating on amazon. However, there are just too many things wrong with this tablet for me to keep it. I charged the tablet for 10 hours before first use as recommended, upon powering the device on it said the battery had no charge! I had to charge it for an additional 5 hours before I got to play around with it. Right upon boot up, I noticed it was not a new device! It had Eastern set time and other settings set up from the previous owner. That irked me alot, as I paid for a new device not a returned one. On with the functionality and user options...

Wi-Fi has awful range. I was literally in my bedroom right next to our other bedroom with the router and I could not get a solid wi-fi connection from less then 10 ft away. However, after resetting the tablet to factory settings I was able to get the wi-fi to work from my bedroom. Walking over another 5 ft to my bathroom or another 10 to my living room and it would lose connection right away. BUMMER! I will list the other problems/dislikes I've had with this tablet.

I recently received a $100 Amazon gift card for Christmas 2014 from my sister, and though I really didn't need or want anything, I eventually used the card for purchase of this, as I couldn't think of anything else at the time.  I had never had a tablet but doing some research in my leisure to use this gift, I finally settled upon this product.  I have an aging, but still powerful computer, in addition to a Roku and an Ouya gaming/media device, but before using my sis's gift card, I really hadn't thought of any personal need for a "tablet."  While that 'need" or lack of one, may still be true, I finally used the gift card and amount to purchase this, and I really couldn't be happier.

There are so many "tablets" out there, including the (to me) overpriced Apple ones, to the cheapest of the cheap, but I figured, if one is to spend around $100, more or less, for a tablet, might as well get the most bang for the buck.  And, this is it.  Basically, you're not going to find any 10.1 inch good tablet for this price, with all of its features, anywhere out there.  You won't find it on the net.  You won't find it on any of the home-shopping channels (ahem, rip off) and you won't find it anywhere on Amazon as well.  For the money, this is the best, I repeat, BEST, 10.1 inch tablet available, feature and spec-wise, at the time of this review, you're going to find.

I have never had a tablet/computer before I purchased this (thanks sister), but I have always wanted one.  Not so much for what such things could do, but because it was just one of those tech devices I had always looked at to buy, but never saw the value for the money I was looking for.  So, I waited.  Seems till now, the features and power of such a tablet. as this, was either always outside of my price range, or offered the features which I never considered worth the price.

Trying to use that gift card for a tablet, I finally settled on this, but overall, after using the thing for a few months, I have to say that this was a really smart buy, and this basically does almost everything any other brand of tablet can do, at a more than competitive price.

So, what's good and bad about this item, and why should you buy it?  First, it has a lot of power.  This is a quad-core tablet, not a dual or single core one.  That means super fast performance.  Second, this has 16G of internal storage (expandable).  Third, this comes with the Google Play store (for Android apps) already pre-installed.  Just set up a Google G-mail account and set up a G-wallet account, and you're good to go for downloading and installing a ton of apps and games and e-books, most of which are free, with no strings attached.  Fourth. it has a mini-HDMI connection (with adaptor cord supplied), which means that you can easily connect this to any large screen TV for hi-def playback.  Finally, but not last, you can expand the memory very easily with a simple SD card, increasing the on-board memory capabilities.

There is a front-facing, and back facing camera function.  Which means you can use this to not only take photos and video, but use it as a Skype device, for 2-way video communications and conferencing..  Granted, the camera functions on this are not the highest quality, which only much more expensive units might handle, but for general purposes, this is more than sufficient for most uses.  And while the audio features of this are a bit lacking, again, for the price, you really can't go wrong in buying this.  Overall, and I must stress this point, you get what you pay for here, and for a starter tablet, with virtually all the most common desired features of a tablet, this is really a steal for the price.

I suggest anyone who is looking for a great quality 10.1 inch tablet to seriously consider purchasing this.  I only touched upon some of the great features and capabilities.  I had some problems setting up the Wi-Fi with this, but those were quickly resolved, especially with the Wi-Fi connectivity apps available on the Google play store, all free, which make resolving any such issues an easy fix.  Overall, after getting through some initial problems in setting this up to satisfaction, I can't emphasis enough how much of a bargain this is.  Don't spend more than you need to with your initial "tablet" experience.  This particular product is the best value for the money you can buy, and I, without any hesitation after much use, can't recommend it more if you're looking for a 10.1 inch tablet with the most desired and needed "tablet" configurations.

The display resolution on this is not that great, considering that available on tablets costing much more than this.  But if you simply can't afford those pricier units for that factor alone, and if you're looking for a really great "starter" tablet experience, with all the basics and most desired features, look no further on Amazon or anywhere else.  Bang for the buck, this is the best 10.1 inch tablet you can buy, period...

I don't consider myself a "techie snob", but I could not deal with the screen resolution on this tablet (1024 x 600). For me, images and videos were fine, but trying to read text on webpages or anywhere on the screen was a real problem. It's not that my eyes are bad, it's that you can see the individual pixels quite easily in text as well as the notifications bar across the top of the tablet. And if a webpage has a lot of smaller text, then the pixels become so obvious in the letters that you cannot even read some of the very small text (that would be no problem with a smartphone or any other device I can remember ever using). For me, this ruins the entire experience and makes the tablet seem far cheaper than even the $100 selling price at the time of my writing this.

Related to this is the viewing angle... I knew this was an issue for some people, but I did not think it would bother me much. I figured it might even keep people from reading over my shoulder on a plane, lol. BUT, there was something very odd about the 'viewing angles' on this tablet that was so bad, I've never seen anything like it. There really was no angle that looked correct to me - everything seemed too light or too dark or too "off" to my eyes somewhere on the screen no matter how I tilted the tablet. The stock wallpaper image on the desktop with which the tablet ships did not do it any favors. If anything, the silver, reflective balls and red and white colors on the wallpaper just highlighted how bad the images looked from almost any angle. Again, though, I thought that most pictures and videos I watched actually looked OK, but there were some things that made the poor viewing angles (or any "viewing" at all) really noticeable.

As another reviewer pointed out, you can also make the screen discolor and deform by pressing anywhere on the backside. I did not have to press very hard at all to make the screen show these 'anomalies'. This actually didn't bother me much, but maybe it would be a problem for some users.

Some other things I didn't care for:

1. I emailed the company's US support about an admittedly tricky issue that the manufacturer maybe couldn't have helped, but I did not receive a response - nothing to even say "we're sorry but we can't help you". So I have to wonder about support in general.

2. The "back/home/open apps" touch controls are located at the bottom of the screen as part of the software - not part of the hardware or bezel of the tablet itself - and on a lot of webpages, I thought this took away valuable real estate. On landscape mode, these controls are a full 1 cm or nearly a full half inch thick. And when you take away the useable space across the top that most apps use up, you are left with surprisingly little actual, viewable space (again, on landscape, at least). I know that other phones and tablets probably do this as well, but I thought I'd mention it as it's the first time I can remember having to deal with it.

3. There was an unnamed internet browser installed as default (not Chrome) that I've never seen before and that I could not seem to be able to uninstall. It's not a big deal, but I wondered if this extra software might be causing some browsing problems related to...

4. Chrome, Firefox, and Dolphin browsers (I tried them all) seemed a little "jerky" at times.

5. My tablet came with a screen protector already installed, and they leave it to you to peel off the outer layer, which is nice. However, there was a big piece of lint trapped underneath in one location, and air bubbles in several (around 5) other locations and I did not feel this was acceptable. In my experience, screen protectors can be incredibly difficult to apply without problems, but that's me, and the manufacturer should have a clean room and be able to do a much better job than I can. I was pretty sure that this was worse than what I could have done myself, but I still didn't want to risk it by redoing it - had I decided to keep the tablet...

I decided to pay the $9.50 or so to return this tablet. I would have been constantly aggravated by it. On the plus side, I will add that battery life seemed fine. I used it off and on for a few days, watching maybe 30 - 60 minutes of videos, downloading numerous apps, checking email, and browsing webpages off and on for several days, and the battery only dropped to around 60%. I'm not saying this tablet has a great battery life, and maybe I didn't use it as much as I thought, but it's not as bad as I read (somewhere I thought I read that it has a 2 - 3 hour battery life. Maybe I misread, but battery life seems to be much higher than that).

So, I would avoid this tablet if you even suspect that the things I mentioned might bug you. I give the manufacturer credit for building a functional, low-cost Android tablet, but I can't deal with it, lol. I do have a suggestion for a different tablet with better screen resolution. The same company, actually, makes/sells another Dragon tablet called "Dragon Touch M10X 10.1'' Quad Core Google Android Tablet PC... HD Screen 1366x768 Display..." for $140. This is a different model that was apparently released on March 2, 2015 with a better screen resolution. I haven't had a chance to try it out yet, but I did order one... fingers crossed. Personally, I'm looking for something like this because I just can't justify spending $300+ on a Samsung or Apple when all I really want is a decent "toy" to check email, websites, and videos. Like I said, fingers crossed that this other tablet will hit the sweet spot of "cheaper" price but with a useable screen - for me, at least.

I hope this review is helpful and saves some people some disappointments and/or hassles.

Tablet arrived extremely quickly and have not had a problem with it in the month that I've owned it. It is easy to use and runs surprisingly fast! Not to mention, the battery life on this is amazing! I was a bit skeptical considering the price, but I've been pleasantly surprised. Unlike other products that claim you'll get so many gb (yet do not factor in the space required for running the actual product processor/etc.), this one legitimately has 16 gb. All the apps play smoothly and it is super nice to have such a low costing tablet have Google Play store on it.

However, I do feel obligated to point out there are a couple issues with the tablet that may bother other individuals. One issue is the speakers are placed on the back of the tablet rather than lining the sides of it. This causes a slight distortion to the sound if you hold it upright or lay it on a table, which that happens to bug me a lot. However, you can resolve this problem by just using earphones (they sound excellent with this tablet). Also, when personalizing the tablet (this seems to be a problem with just the recent Android update because I have a family member who bought a different tablet with Android 4.4.2 and it illustrated the same issue) is when you try to put a wallpaper on it, it automatically wants to zoom in even if you have edited it to fit the screen. This is problematic and slightly irritating because it zooms in way too much that it distorts pictures. I personally like to have certain wallpapers to fit like I would like them and not look pixelated. However, you could get used to it eventually or find certain pictures that don't look too bad with the "extreme zoom."

Despite those two problems, which of course you can completely live with them (especially for this price!), I am extremely happy with this purchase and definitely recommend this if you are looking for a fast and efficient tablet for a good price!

I shopped around (a lot) for a reasonably priced, full-featured android tablet for my wife before making a purchase, and when I saw the Dragon Touch A1X, and read the many positive reviews about it, decided to give it a try. This 10.1" tablet far surpassed our expectations in terms of performance and quality of workmanship. It shipped with Kit Kat, the latest Android OS, and which is very fast and easy to use.

I read some reviews about how the back warps the image if pressed too hard, but I couldn't reproduce that, even when pressing pretty hard on it to see if it would. Perhaps Dragon Touch has improved the back, making it stronger, but in any case, it's not a problem for me. My wife loves it, and so far, she's had no problems at all. For the price, this will be hard to beat. Why spend 5-6 hundred bucks for a "name brand" tablet, when this one does everything you want it to for less than $150?

Purchased this device to help assist and protect an 81 year old woman.  It was meant to be paired with a Ring Video Doorbell and neither has worked very well.  Its slow (its supposed to be a quad core?) with almost no RAM.  But the primary problem is that it doesn't integrate with the Ring Doorbell well at all.  And sadly, Ring appears to know this.  One of their techs said I should really return this and spend an additional $300 to $400 to buy an Apple product as they apparently work seamlessly.  Great, thanks for letting me know after the fact.  :(

One other real problem with this "system" (and I do use the term very loosely) is that it only comes with USB power.  Maybe thats OK for others but it doesn't work for our needs.  If the Ring "system" is to work correctly then my understanding is the video portion needs to be powered most of the time.  We don't want the machine powering down when someone comes to the door.  We need it running all the time (which is fine with us as long as the "system" works.  The system also came with a keyboard which is pretty handy for an elderly woman with severe arthritis in her hands.  But, the keyboard and the power need the same USB port.  So the keyboard under the current "system" is worthless and a waste of money.

Now, I did order a power supply and it finally got here after about three weeks.  Tried to hook it up a little while ago only to find its too small for the power port.  Another piece of junk which will have to be sent back.

So this thing may be OK for the young but not those trying to protect and assist their parents.  It just doesn't work and is a complete waste of time and money.  Better to spend the funds on wired products for now.  Maybe this stuff will work in the future but it doesn't now.

Btw, this may sound like the rant of someone with no experience in the field whatsoever.  That would be incorrect.  My mother knows nothing of this stuff but I've actually been working on PC's for close to 30 years now.  This experience with Ring and this Tablet reminds me of the bad old DOS days.

TL;DR: Budget tablet at great price, but while you get a large tablet with decent performance, you give up a nice screen (horrible viewing angle) and poor quality/finish (plastic backing, awful camera/speakers and headphone/AUX jack doesn't work). 3 stars = It's ok for the price

After playing with this over the weekend, I feel like I can write a solid review. The Good: First off, the price beats anything around it ($109 or $119 if you waited too long) and is >50% less than the Galaxy Tab 4 at this point. So with that in mind I was expecting a tablet with roughly half the capacity of the Galaxy. I was pleasantly surprised with the performance. While this quad-core CPU won't beat an iPad or other high-end tablets, I had very little lag watching HD movies (720p or 1080p) or loading the large .pdf textbooks. I also streamed Netflix, which lagged a bit, but that may be more due to my spotty WIFI, so we'll just ignore that for now. It also has access to the Google Play store and its many awesome apps (which is why I bought it over the Kindle HDX). Finally, it has a great selection of input/outputs like microSD capacity, micro-usb, micro-hdmi slots.

Now for the reasons why it only got 3 stars. I bought this to watch movies on during flights and also so I wouldn't have to lug around 10 huge textbooks to my clinical internship. As a book-reader it performs ok as long as you use a high-contrast background, but for watching movies it is sub-par due to the horrible viewing angle. I am watching House of Cards right now on it as I write this on my laptop, but can only make out what is  going on when the tablet is tilted 25-50 degrees in landscape orientation (I measured using a goniometer, it's even worse in portrait orientation). This was hardly noticeable when I initially was testing it out since I had it propped up in a new case at 45 degrees, so if you are only going to use this tablet on a large desk that you can move it back and forth to find the optimal viewing angle, it's fine. But for the vast majority of people that want to use it to some other capacity ie. watch movies in bed, on a plane, take notes in class etc. it simply falls short. I find I have to prop it up with my knees in bed or keep  my wrists constantly flexed which gets annoying real quick. Another sub-par feature is the camera. To be honest the allegedly "5MP" back-facing camera is pretty much unusable unless you are okay with circa-1999 picture quality. I won't even address the 2MP front-facing camera, hopefully you have another computer to Skype with.

Another strike against this tablet is the speakers. They are tinny with low volume capacity, but I really wouldn't care very much about the speakers since I usually just plug in my headphones anyways... but the headphone/AUX jack does not work! This is the largest strike against this tablet! I have plugged in three completely different headphones in and none of them work, all you get is the background audio track with garbled dialogue. I tested it with different tv shows, videos, netflix, itunes etc. The only way you can get them to work is to unplug them slightly, whereupon one ear will work great, and then both ears will work great and you almost forget how frustratingly annoying it is until you move or shift posture just the tiniest bit...and then only one ear will work. My girlfriend bought the exact same tablet and is having the exact problems mentioned above. Maybe we both got lemons...but not likely. This may prove to be the deal breaker for me since watching movies and being able to read a book without keeping it at a specific angle are why I bought the tablet.

Conclusion: if you want a cheap table that has decent performance, access to Google Play, upgradable microSD and lots of inputs/outputs, but also has a bad screen and viewing angle, awful speakers, horrible camera and a non-working headphone/AUX jack...then this is the tablet for you!

I would like to begin that it takes me a lot to leave a poor review. I often believe that if there is something wrong I must have done it and work hard to resolve it. That is also why I am very careful to avoid mishaps. For this product, the Dragon Touch A1X Plus I have done all that can be done.

I would like to begin with the pros:

+Conveniently priced
+Nice Logo
+Able to connect to the USB tablet keyboard that did not work with my previous Acer A500.

That is all for that. I purchased this tablet because my A500 finally sputtered out after years of loyalty. While it had become difficult in its dying days, primarily shutting off randomly, it still performed beautifully. Nice sound, picture, and still compatible with many applications with a decent processor. But it's gone and I needed a new one for my mother-in-law. She only surfed the net, played solitaire and tetris, and listened to soothing music. How strong of a tablet could I actually need?

I knew already that the Dragon Touch was an off brand tablet, but the reviews were amazingly high for ssuch a decent price. I already know of the customer service ideal that every one negative review is about ten people who did not say anything, but even the math didn't add up to make it a bad product. I did note the most frequent complaints:

- Lagging screen
- Freezing
- Random shut offs
- Cheap casing
- Awkward navigation

I purchased it and when it arrived we plug it up right away as per the instructions. When it was appropriate we tuned it on and began. The initial set up was like every Android Device. Once that was said and done we handed her the device. It did annoy me that the Menu, Home, and Back keys were on screen navigation rather than case buttons. The picture was bright but noticeably grainy and immediately the lag as detected. The case was just as cheap as described. Lightly preessing the back showed feedback in the front. Because we were immediately putting it in a case we ignored this factor.

In about a day we noticed the connectin problems. My mother-in-law loves listening to calming music early in the morning and instead of having to click constantly on youtube to keep a playlist going we suggested Pandora. Well, it took nearly an hour to download. Initially, it could not find the network which was weird that every other device was connected. I set it airplane mode, then off. I turned off the wifi, than back on. Reset up her configuration, even shut it off and on!

This became an on and off problem throughout the passing month. Normal stylus with the rubber tip also had difficulty being detected. Pressing uncomfortably hard each time was the only way it would register. Because fine tip stylus are in short supply for android (and I actively use my Jot Pro for art) she simply abandoned the stylus. Even that was bareably.

Then came the freezing. Some apps simply froze the device and it would hang for ages before it shut off. Sometimes it would need to be forced off. This became a regular thing. Also, often it took long holds of the power button for it come on. Even several tries. The process became a guessing game of when it would finally come on, stay on, and work properly. I felt terrible that I had gotten this for her and she was forced to suffice with this tempermental paperweight.

So, it has come to this point that I must give up another hundred to two for a undeinably better product. I guess the tablet market is not like laptops. When shopping for laptops if you really do only the most basic things there is decent laptop for you at a decent price. Beware of this. I might even switch to a Windows 2 in 1 so she can avoid this issue altogether.

The sound quality is horrible. You can barely hear anything, and it sounds like the voices are muffled. It's even worse when you plug in your headphones. You hear the music, but any background voices to movies sound so far off into the distance. Anyway, that was my first problem. My other problem is that on some sites like FB or other images I look at on the net, aren't crisp and clear. It's annoying. That, and if you see an image you like on google, for some reason it will not save the file even after I click save image. I have to go on my phone, send the image to my e-mail, open the image in my e-mail on the tablet, and then save the image that way. All I wanted was a simple wallpaper image. It said something about playing 3D games....I couldn't tell. I downloaded 3D games from google play, and they were not 3D.
I mean, I did spend 100 bucks on it, so you get what you pay for. The price originally said 300. I can see it being worth 100 bucks.....maybe, but I don't see how it was ever 300. I feel like the price was jacked up and then put on "sale" to make people think they were getting a good deal. This was a crappy buy on my end. My cheap straight talk phone that I got from walmart is much better quality than this tablet. Anyway, if anything, it is really nice for reading my comics and manga. The size is the only decent thing about it. That and I can carry it around a lot more easier than my laptop, but if I ever lost or broke this thing....I wouldn't be sad. I'm only sad at the money I wasted on it.

Only important drawback that will only affect a small group of people is the front facing camera does not properly line up to the center of of the screen without holding the tablet at an angle so if Skyping or front camera usage is your purpose, then your cell phone still still might might be your best choice for for that. Would be a five five star if not not for that part. This tablet is easily worth it's price. Absolutely zero buyers remorse.

After a lot of shopping around I settled on a dragon touch and decided on the large one so there was a nice sized on screen keyboard to eliminate the need for a Bluetooth or USB one later. We are only on day 2, but can find no flaws once you accept what it is. Packaging was simple, yet secure, no expensive and unnecessary over packaging. Powered on well, logged on to my WiFi quick, logged on to Google, and we were away. The apps download quickly, the resolution is not like a $1000 tablet, but is better than some I've seen going for 2-3 times as much, and honestly is better than I thought it would be. The cameras are not real sharp, but then I didn't buy it for the cameras to begin with, and after a few Skype sessions we decided it was more than adequate for casual use, after all I paid twice as much for a nice Cannon if I want pictures. We only play simple games, social meidia , the kids watch movies in the car, and web search, but it accomplishes those tasks flawlessly. Have decided to buy the kids a couple of the smaller 7-8in Dragon Touch tablets due to the wide variety of activity's for toddlers and young children through Google play. Overall a 5star entry level or casual use tablet.

I am writing this review because on NON-service support from TabletExpress. I ordered the Dragon Touch A1X Plus 10.1" tablet though Amazon. When I turned on the tablet, I saw a beautiful screen with all text in ITALIAN. All pages were in Italian. I was hoping for a quick fix or an exchange for a tablet in English so  I called the company's customer service telephone number (not a toll free number but one with a 301 area code). I got a recorded message that went something like "due to the heavy volume of telephone calls, we cannot answer your call but you can e-mail us at CS@tabletexpress.com. and we will respond within 24 hours." I tried calling once a day for 3 days and got the same message. I tried sending e-mail messages about the problem and never got a response. So I repacked the tablet and returned it.
It's too bad this happened. The tablet's pages looked very good, perfect for my needs (e-mails, surfing the net, ordering from Amazon, etc.). I would give it a 3 star rating because TabletExpress has poor quality control -  sending a tablet for Italian customers. I knocked the  rating down to 1 star for complete lack of customer support.
If you are looking for a basic tablet with good graphics capability and for  e-mails and surfing the net, this tablet would seem to be a good choice. But be aware that you might receive NO customer support if there is a problem.

Pruchased this to do Wifi heat mapping.  All the Window's based tools were more expensive than the laptop running Windows.  So decided to give this a shot, and very glad that I did.  Even though it is not the latest/greatest bleeding edge processor, the speed and responsiveness is excellent, and the hardware never an issue with speed.  The graphics are crisp and clear, and I was able to produce the wifi heat maps that the bosses wanted in very little time.

If you are looking to get more familiar with Android, or need a table that is useful without breaking the bank, this is the perfect option!  I was not expecting much from a unit at this price point, but have been extremely happy with the unit.

My kids have been using this tablet for more than 2 weeks and this works flawlessly.
I have no problem with wifi connection, tablet usability, speed etc. Battery lasts close to 3 days with medium use (2-3 hours a day playing you tube videos and kids games), almost same as my nexus and samsung tab2.
Video quality is good, not as crip as nexus or samsung (as expected), but this tablet comes with mini hdmi (haven't tried it yet, waiting for the cable), SD card slot etc.

My only complaint is the sound quality. I tried the same video on all 3 tablets and the audio is distorting starting around 75% volume level. May be there is a setting that I can tweak, but since this is for kids, I didn't bother to look much into it.
The tablet needs to held a bit tilted backward to see it properly (which I find it strange and never saw the same behavior with any other tablets), not a big deal either.
Chromecast works fine and no issues with video or audio, so both these issues not an issue for me.

Overall, I am satisfied with the tablet for the intended purpose (kids use). If you are looking for a cheap tablet that is not used for your premium video viewing, then this may be a good purchase.

This Dragon Touch is faster than those old tablets, but not even in the same galaxy as a 2 year old or newer tablet of this size and reputable build.

I bought this tablet to replace a Motorola Xoom that had developed a problem with the screen.  I was initially looking at something that cost three times as much and had all the latest bells and whistles, but I saw this listed on the page under What Other Items Do Customers Buy After Viewing This Item?  I am leery of no-name brand tablets (Ive been burned in the past), but the price, and the overwhelmingly positive reviews drew me in.

The tablet arrived 2 days ago and it has been a very pleasant surprise.  It is much lighter than my old Xoom, and much faster.  The screen pixels aren't as dense as some of the latest high-end machines, but for my purposes (email, light web surfing and the occasional video) the screen is perfectly fine.  Also, the rear facing camera is barely adequate, but I don't use the camera for anything other than depositing checks, and it works fine for that.

My only real complaint, and it may seem like a quibble, is how short the cord is on the charger.  It will not reach from the powerstrip on my floor to the top of my desk  which is kind of silly.

I would not hesitate to recommend this to anyone that is looking for a capable tablet.  It isn't the latest and greatest, but for the price, it is really very, very good.

I have had to knock off two stars.  The tablet has developed an annoying buzz from  one of the speakers.  It is not a subtle "do you here something?" kind of buzz, but more of a "what the heck is that annoying sound?" kind of buzz.  It renders the tablet pretty much unusable.  I will be returning it.

I wasn't sure if a tablet would because useful device for me or just one more thing to stuff in my bag along with my smartphone, Kindle, and laptop. I knew I wanted a 10 inch tablet for the flexibility. I figured that I should give a budget tablet a try and not drop several hundred dollars on something I might not use.

After reading the reviews for this tablet I went ahead and gave it a try knowing that there might be some shortcomings (there are). But overall it's not a bad buy for a basic tablet that you're not asking too much from. I picked up the recommended Finite case and it has done its job.

PROS:

1. 10 inch tablet for a low price.

2. Nice design and color scheme.

3. Feels fairly solid.

3. Screen protector pre-applied. Bubbles were few, no worse than if I had tried to do it myself.

4. No problems connecting to Wi-Fi or Bluetooth and holding signal.

5. Runs well for basic tasks. I've also used Netflix and Crunchyroll without issue. I haven't tried playing games on it.

6. Visuals. Colors come through pretty well. Bright and clear with decent resolution. I've watched Snowpiercer, RWBY, and Sword Art Online on Netflix and they looked good.

CONS:

1. Viewing angles. As stated in many reviews, it's not very good. You're going to need a pretty dead on view to avoid saturation / white out with colors. In landscape mode I've found tilting left or right to not be an issue, but forward and back is the most problematic for viewing. I knew this issue going in, so I'm dealing with it as is.

2. Speakers/Sound. I wasn't expecting much. There's nothing great here. With headphones the audio is decent. You're working with a budget tablet. **I have noticed a popping/crackling sound from the speaker when some audio files start. The sound is audible even when the audio on the device is off. It may need a return if this is not normal. **

3. Stylus input. I had little success getting a stylus to work with the tablet. I tried a Wacom Bamboo Solo and a Musemee Notier. The screen just is not responsive enough. I had hoped to do this, but that will have to wait until I move on to a higher end tablet.

4. Screen. The touch capabilities, responsiveness can be a little off. Sometimes I'll have to touch more than once to get the right response, or I will mis-click because it did not read where I was inputting.

Again, I'm satisfied overall with the device. If you know what you're getting you likely won't be disappointed and frankly a bit impressed with a 10 inch tablet in this price range that can perform to this degree. The speaker issue my prompt a return, but I would be comfortable with getting a replacement and I would recommend the tablet with the aforementioned caveats.

It works. For how long remains to be seen.  I've been working with PC's, tablets and phones for a long time so I know the in's and outs of computers and networks.  I have MAC filtering enabled on my router as an added security measure.  Most devices have a MAC (Media Access Code) address that is specific to every device.

First thing I did, as I always do is to get the device connected to the network and check for any updates to software, firmware, etc.  I located the MAC address on this tablet, entered it in to the router and made the connection.  After a reboot, the tablet would not connect to the network.  I checked the MAC address to what I had entered into the router to confirm I typed it in correctly.  The address was way off.  I did another reboot, and the MAC address had changed again.  This is the first time I've ever encountered an issue like this.

I searched high and low and got a lot of different answers.  From bad hardware, or the kernal is corrupt or because a static MAC address isn't licensed so a random MAC address is generated with each reboot.

I haven't decided yet whether or not to return it as it's a gift for my mother-in-law.  She's not a heavy user, but wanted something simple and not too expensive.  So I got this tablet.  It works, but not on a MAC filtered network.  The speakers are pitiful and the sound not good.  She'll have to wear head phones to get any decent sound.

So if it were for me, I'd return it.  For someone else, determine how much they will use it and if you want to pay more for something of better quality.  For the price, as the saying goes, you get what you pay for.

I should have known better. I much preferred my junky old Le Pan II compared to this Dragon Touch A1X. Unfortunately, the Le Pan II finally got screen cracked after being dropped one too many times (perhaps 10 times! -- yet it still survived). Waste of time and money. For $317 more, you get a FAR superior product. No more Android tablets for me.  Good luck.

I started to say that this is an excellent 10.1" tablet for the price, but that would be an insult to this tablet.  This is an excellent 10.1" tablet period, and it would still be a good value if it were priced like the other 10.1" tablets -- and it isn't!  It is as fast as I need it to be for anything that I do.  It has an excellent display. It has a good amount of memory and it also has a SanDisk port for more storage. All around nice job.

For the first 6 months, it worked great!  I loved it and wrote a glowing review... That was in February... Come August, it began malfunctioning constantly... and now, I can't even charge it up without holding the charger cord at a weird angle to even get the 'charging' icon... It doesn't stay on by itself, so I'd have to hold it all night to even get 10% charge as it simply doesn't work anymore... Worse, even the one time that I managed to get it fully charged, it died in less than 5 minutes and turned itself off again... with a dead battery... Useless now...

The one year guarantee?  A bald-faced lie...  They claim that it is only 90 days for defective models... and 1 year for SOFTWARE only... Except it's never the software because you cannot return it to be evaluated for what the problem actually is... They state that it is NOT software related without ever even seeing it... How can they tell via email?  They can't... Obviously, it's a scam and highly deceptive.... I bought it ONLY because it supposedly came with a full, unlimited one year warranty because other models I'd purchased were crap too... I figured with such a good warranty that it would be a good product... WRONG... It's crap and the 1 year warranty is bogus...

I can't get my money back, but anyone reading this can save theirs for a better product... DO NOT BUY this... You WILL be sorry... Read all of the other 1 star reviews... They all say pretty much the same thing... buyer beware!!

EDIT: I complained to Amazon about their false 1 year warranty and they quickly refunded my $$... Don't take no for an answer from the seller if yours goes kablooey, contact Amazon for help... Why Amazon still allows it to be sold?  I simply do not know...

This tablet is amazing! It is easy to set up, syncs with Bluetooth devices in a flash, comes with a protective screen cover already applied, and is relatively lightweight for a tablet of its size. It also does not come bogged down with a lot of useless apps installed, and I have had no issues with WiFi connections other than when we went out of town - but then again, I would blame the resort, not the tablet (my husband had issues connecting as well). Hello:  I am a consultant setting up the tablet for a business so that they can play videos at a trade show.  The video is 30 MB. When I clicked on it (like I do for my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2), instead of getting a file structure so I could copy the video from my PC to the tablet, I get a message asking me to insert a disk into the DVD.  I reviewed all the posts on the Internet, and nowhere could I find a solution.  I even configured the tablet to accept USB file structure connections.  Nothing worked.  Then I called their hep line, only to get a message saying they were too busy to accept calls, and to email them.  OK.. Next I tried Google Drive to download the video.  After 4 hours, it still never made it to my Dragon Touch.  While the features of the tablet seemed good, it failed miserably in the ability to connect to a PC and show its file structure.  I tried connecting using Windows 7, Windows 8, and Windows XP... nothing worked.  I attached a picture of what I am seeing.  Oh... and if there were special setups, they were not documented in the pamphlet that came with the unit, nor could I find solutions on their web site.

I researched extensively before deciding on this Dragon Touch A1XPlus 10" screen Tablet. I am completely impressed! I bought this for my son, who wanted a tablet for his digital art. So I was not exactly sure what to expect with the screen resolution. But I could not afford the pricey tablets suggested for artists, so again, after much review and research (b/c this was the first tablet I have bought), it was a good decision - no issues with screen resolution and with the quad-core, it is fast. I (and my son) really like the 10" screen. I do not feel it is too big - just right. So glad I bought an Android with the many  apps to choose from in the Google Play store. This was well worth the $109.00 I spent for this. The only thing that threw me a little was that the memory card slot says "TF" card. After learning something new myself, the TF stands for Trans Flash, which is the original name for the micro SD memory card. So do not let that deter you. Thank you!

Overall, the Dragon A1X Plus is a solid deal.  It has all the performance and features that most people would want in a tablet.  There are a few areas where it will not compare to a top of the line name brand tablet, but for the price it certainly delivers.

-- Initial Impression --
Out of the box, the A1X Plus is large and feels solid.  All of the connections are on one side of the tablet which is convenient and works well with a case.  The A1X Plus is solid but not super heavy. It is a well balanced device that is light without feeling cheap (even though it is all plastic).

-- Performance --
The tablet came mostly charged and turned on quickly. The power/lock button and the volume buttons on the side are responsive and appropriately sized.  The quad core processor handled any task I threw at it with ease.  The screen has good color coverage and viewing angle.  The screen isn't as smooth (in terms of physical touch) as a higher end device, so swiping through pictures or pages takes a little getting used to.  It still works fine it just doesn't have the same feel as a $400 tablet.

-- Apps --
Android 4.4 is nice and this implementation has no noticeable bloatware.  It comes with the Google play store and ran all the apps I tried.  I did notice one limitation when trying various apps.  For some apps the tilt controls did not work.  The tilt controls work fine for rotating the tablet, but when trying to play a game that requires tilt sensitivity, things didn't seem to be working properly.

-- I/O --
As far as inputs and outputs, this tablet has everything.  Charge and USB OTG via Micro USB.  The USB OTG works well. It instantly recognized my keyboard case and I was typing in seconds.  HDMI out and Micro SD card slot are both very useful features.  WIFI is fast and reliable, no dropouts.

In summary, the A1X Plus is a great deal.  It is a good combination of performance, features and price.

Well, here we go.  This is the first budget 10in tablet I have bought.  I have an ASUS MeMO HD which I love but I needed a bigger screen.  When I got this, I turned it on and was very impressed with what I found.  The screen is crisp at a certain angle and great for reading or doing Pinterest.  I have loaded TuneIn radio and netflix and have no complaints on speed or talk radio quality even tho the EQ is a bit tinney.  This does not have any EQ options built in.  What you hear is what you hear....I can live with that.

The speed has been fine but I am still working with getting a proper stylus.  The two I have seem to stick and you have to have a firmer touch on the screen....again for $109, I can live with it.  The thing that IS THE WORST...and I do mean the WORST, is the camera.  If you use your tablet for any kind of photos you can forget this one if you're inside.  It is like being underwater looking through glasses smeared with vaseline.  I will say one thing, the Asus MeMO HD has a great camera that has taken fantastic pictures inside and out.  The Dragontouch has no photo setting outside of the bare bones.

If you don't care about good photos then you are set.  This really is a very decent tablet for newbies and pros that don't require a super behemoth machine.  You can read in comfort.  The battery life is decent and the build seems to be very good.  I have not had any issue with any app I have loaded.  If you are new to tablets or an older person that is new to the tablet technology, this is a great choice without breaking the bank.

I am seriously thinking of getting my Mother one of these.  It will do 3 times what she would need and only cost $109.  In the end, that is hard to beat.  Just my .02 cents

What initially attracted me to this tablet was the screen size, high reviews, and the price.  I was looking at netbooks, but this tablet looked like it would satisfy my needs, so I took the plunge and ordered it.  I am glad I did.  It was very easy to add all the apps I needed through the Google Play store and also to add custom wallpaper.  The apps load quickly and I have not experienced any stalling.  When I change the direction of the tablet the screen instantly changes and there is no lag.  This is a testament of the fast processor.  I have not had any problem connecting to my wifi network at home.  The internet worked right away after connecting and there was no lag moving from one page to another.  I have watched some YouTube videos and it plays perfectly.  I am even able to open up Word documents with no problems which is great for meetings.  My books on Amazon Kindle and my Bible app also loaded fast and was easy to read with the 10.1 inch screen. So for productivity I give this five stars.  The only reason why I gave the whole review 4 stars instead of 5 is because the screen resolution is not as good as I hoped, however I have gotten used to it and it works fine for reading emails and general productivity. The plastic material the tablet is made from seems a little cheap and thin, however with a tablet case I will have no problems.  I realize this is a budget tablet, so there needs to be some give and take.  Overall I think it is a great deal, and I am happy with this purchase.

Pros: Inexpensive. Large screen. High resolution screen with good color reproduction.  Fast CPU.  Maintains WiFi connection well.

Cons: Unusually limited viewing angle on the screen. Speakers are so tinny that they are hard to listen to.  The coating on the screen is oddly dry and a bit hard on the fingertips.

Overall: I bought this tablet mainly for two purposes--to play internet connected games and to stream videos.  It does a really good job on the games, especially compared to my previous tablet, which had terrible problems staying connected to the WiFi network.  For streaming videos, however, it falls short of what I had hoped for.  The streaming part is OK (smooth play, no buffer underflow) and the picture is good, if viewed at the optimum angle; however the limited viewing angle and harsh tinny speakers are a let-down.  Overall, I would say that better tablets are available if you want to pay top dollar, but this one is a reasonably good deal for the price.

I had this tablet for only about a week at this point and I'm very impressed with it's performance. I mention the length of time because one of the biggest problems with these low cost tablets is their durability. My last $100 Irulu tablet lasted for about 3 weeks before complete failure. Amazon provided a refund quickly and painlessly. Time will tell the complete story on this one. As far as performance goes it does everything I ask it to without any glitches. Keyboard works great, much better than the Irulu it replaced, apps download quickly and it easily finds WiFi hot spots and connects. Overall quality and feel of the tablet seems pretty good for it's price point. Personally I think it's nuts to spend big bucks on a name brand tablet when one of these will do the job just as well. I can only hope the long term reliability is not an issue with this Dragon Touch as it was with my last purchase.

Pros:
1 - 10 inch screen
2 - Quad core processor
3 - 16GB flash
4 - Good battery life
5 - Stable operation (doesn't crash)
6 - Bluetooth
7 - GPS (it seems to sort-of work but sub-zero outside temperature prevented testing at this time)

Cons:
1 - Very limited viewing angle
2 - Terrible cameras
3 - Awful speaker

Testing:
Since there are already so many other reviews, I only tested Kodi (XBMC) and sadly, although it runs, the video acceleration hardware is unsupported (as of this writing).  If you turn off hardware acceleration you get a picture but at less than 1 frame per second, it is pretty much useless.

Comments:
While seriously lacking in several key areas, I only removed 1 star from my rating because price must always be considered.  Expecting a high resolution IPS screen at this price would be ridiculous and comparing this tablet to a Nexus or iPad equally so.  While not a high end tablet, the A1X Plus gets all the basics right.  It has a lot of memory, it has extremely stable operation, it is very fast, it balances well when you're holding it, the case texture has a nice feel and on and on.

In particular, I removed the star because the speaker is beyond poor sounding.  One could understand that an IPS panel is very expensive but a speaker??  Another 99 cents would have made a world of difference in the sound of the speaker.  If the manufacturer/seller ever reads this review, please, Please, PLEASE guys, get the sound right.  Low cost and cheap aren't the same thing so make the sacrifices where they make sense and not to save a dollar.

Although I plan to try several other tablets before making my final decision on which 6 will be in my game room, I will definitely keep this one for myself.  I highly recommend this tablet for a budget purchase.

I've had this tablet for almost a month and I'm extremely impressed by it. A list of what I do and don't like about it:

Display: Given that the display isn't HD at 1024x600, it shows both games and videos extremely well. True, I'm not a real gamer, preferring more casual games like cards, casinos and hidden object games to any kind of action games, but it shows action in movies such as The Matrix and The Hobbit extremely well. I particularly like that I can add movies to a 32 gb Micro SD card and watch from there. I was pleased that the dark scenes don't seem overly dark as they did on earlier tablets I had.

Having said the above, though, I have to note that viewing angle is vital with this tablet, because you need to be looking at it just right or the color either washes out or seems extremely dark. That's where a good case comes in handy and is why I love the Fintie Dragon Touch A1X case I bought on Amazon, it's attractive and lets me keep the tablet at just the right angle while using and protected when not.

Sound: The audio on this isn't spectacular, but I have no trouble hearing it at home as I do with other devices. I can play music on the tablet, go 20 feet away to the kitchen and the music is very clear and audible. Speaking of audible, it's great for playing audiobooks. I use Smart Audiobook player from the Google play store, a free app that I chose to support. It's far better than my cell phone for listening to audiobooks because the sound is clearer. As for other apps, Pandora, Netflix and Umano sound great as does HBO Go. Max Go is a little low in volume, but not as bad as Showtime for Android, which is very low volume. Max Go has given me problems with other devices, but this is the only device I'e had trouble with the Showtime app. Not a big concern, as the offerings from Showtime Go are considerably less than those of other video streaming services. I was disappointed to find no way to use Amazon Prime video as apparently it's not yet compatible with Android.

Apps: The apps I use most often, aside from the above mentioned apps, are Buzzfeed, Reddit is Fun, Kindle, IFTTT, Flipboard, News360, Tunein Radio, Youtube, Podcast Addict, DoubleDown Casino and Jewel Legends. I've recently been playing Hidden Expedition Hope Diamond and have had a few times when I've had trouble finding objects because the screen seemed too small, but pinch and zoom generally solves that problem, as does finding the correct angle for viewing the scene. Other apps and games work fine with little to no buffering or delay in displaying content.

Storage: I find the 16gb storage native to this very limiting, which is why I use the 32gb micro SD card. Others have said a 64gb micro SD card will work, but it hasn't for me. I CAN use a 64gb flash drive with a micro USB OTG adapter (no, you can't plug a flash drive directly into it.) For this reason (experience with this and other tablets and computers), I've learned to carry flash drives with me whenever I go somewhere distant. I can carry videos on one, audiobooks on another and games on a third. Fortunately they all fit perfectly into holders in either my pocketbook or the Case Logic 15" laptop briefcase I've been using.

Battery: I read in another review about the battery only lasting 1 to 2 hours - that would have been a deal breaker for me. My testing has shown the battery to last for 5 to 6 hours streaming video, an hour or two longer if not online. This is excellent battery life in my opinion. The streaming was mostly video (1 hour of Bill Maher, a 90 minute movie, 2 40 minute tv episodes and watching Youtube for an hour as well as listening to a 30 minute podcast). After all that, the battery showed 8% battery left, so I charged it by connecting to a USB cable on my laptop. Yes, that takes longer than using the included AC charger, but the cable on my laptop is 6 feet, as opposed to the 2 feet cable that is the AC charger. I don't know how long it takes to charge, but I do know it was back to 100% after 10 hours connected to my laptop.

I really like this tablet. Yes, there are a few things I would change or add, including a better instruction manual - you're better off watching Youtube videos than trying to learn how to use it from the manual. The sound buttons on the side still confuse me as I'm never sure which is the volume up or down. I quickly learned that touching the top left of the screen brings up notifications and touching the top right brings up the settings menu (which is very well done with fast access to WIFI and other quick settings, as well as the expanded settings menu.) True, there really is no GPS on here, but that's what I use my phone for, not a 10" tablet.

well..... where to begin. I read the reviews and everyone raved about it. I researched it on youtube and still found nothing really negative about this tablet. I was iffy but I still purchased two. Ooops! I gave it a one star so you would read this, but in honesty it probably earns 3 stars, personally however I cant stand it. The resolution is poor. Even my simple poker game looks ugly. The backgrounds are weird looking. The whites and darks are ugly. I cant stress it enough, this is why this product is cheap. Now onto speed. Its not horrible but Im clueless why everyone in the videos and reviews says it screams. Seems average, maybe a little above average. Ok, the sound. Tinny is what comes to mind. Pretty scrappy speakers. Battery life......... Well I charged it the recommended 10 freakin hours and used it for about 1.5 hour, installing, playing poker, surfing, and I got it down to 89%. Is that good, or bad, I don't know. Probably, once again, average. I knew right away the screen was going to be an issue. just the charging icon alone before even booting up sent alarms and whistles off in my head. Okay, final say...... For a gift? maybe.... perfect for kids or old people that don't even know what resolution is. I also want to add I baught a Samsung tab from Walmart days earlier, ended up returning it because of the massive price difference between Walmart and amazon. I was all set to buy the 8 inch tab for 199 then I found this..... Wish I wouldn't of been a cheap skate. Like I said, for me its a one star tablet, for others it could be a 3.5. I don't know why anyone would rate it higher unless they are uninformed of whats actually out there. Theres still great deals on name brands, spend that extra $50... Makes me wonder if those people are paid on youtube to do these reviews and not mention the resolution. The built in hdmi might be cool, but never tried it. I mean, wouldn't it project the 1200x600 onto my 42in tv, I couldn't imagine that looking good. having the large screen would be awesome, if it had the resolution to back it up. don't buy unless you know all this.

This tablet needs 10 stars!!  At least that's what I think.  Per instructions, I plugged it in to charge the battery. But that was not needed because I received the message that the battery was at 100%  Since my smart phone is Android driven, it was easy for me to find my way around this device.  Most of the reveiwers have made many comments about this tablet, so I'm going to mention other things that impressed me.  How about over 70 ringtones.  Even one called "Heaven".  If you fill up the first screen with icons from the Google Play Store, there is a second screen you can start filling up!  The FM Radio is an unique feature of this tablet.  In 'search' mode the tablet looks for all the FM frequencies available to where I'm located.  There were 77 frequencies, so I made them ALL presets.  Any time I want a particular station, I just choose that preset.  Nice, huh?  One of the frequencies is on the fringe area, but this tablet has a very sensitive receiver and I could hear it without any "white noise'.  I'm impressed with the FM feature.  I downloaded the Ookla speed test app from Google Play and was surprised to note that the speed dial was 'pegged' at 50mbps to start, then settled down to 40+mbps.  VERY FAST!  Enough said.  In short, this is a fine tablet at an amazing price.

Beware,  It says it has Google Play installed but it's not - it redirects you to an overseas site.  I bought this specifically to run one application (BitGym).  When I went to the Play store, it was not there.  I then went to the vendor site and clicked on the link to install at the Play Store.  It took me there (the real Store) and when I attempted to install the app, it would not.  It said the app was not compatible with the device.  Apparently, this happens with low end Chinese tablets.  They do not pay a license fee to Google so they cannot install from the real Play Store. Many other apps apparently are at the alternate site (i.e. Spotify) and they do install and run.

I just upgraded from a 1st-gen Kindle Fire to the A1X Plus. At first I was somewhat hesitant when opened the box. Yes, it's not ultra-thin like a Samsung, but it's still thinner than many on the market. The fact it runs 4.4.2, one of the latest versions of Android, was a big selling point. Note: Google just announced version 5.1, so it's not quite cutting-edge, but that's okay. For me I'd rather be a little bit behind the curve with a stable, patched release.

The screen is quite large. The bezel doesn't encroach too much on the real estate, which was a plus for me. I expect if TabletExpress continues to develop newer models this will get even smaller. But for me this is more than adequate.

Games and video (both SD and HD) seem to play just fine. HDMI output was again, a nice plus, and I'm glad I went for this model instead of the 9".

The instruction manual does have some weak points, as others have indicated in their reviews. The power adapter that came with mine was in fact a USB-style, not the older DC pole-style port, which is displayed in the manual. And even though the English in the manual can take a second reading to fully understand, it isn't rocket science and for the price I'm willing to put up with it.

Setup and charging was a breeze. Having Google Play Store gave me the greatest access to apps for Android that I think I could have.

In short: It's worth the price. You get a decent tablet with a big screen and one of the latest versions of Android.

Decent product for the price. The encryption gave me an error on the first decryption. But luckily I just started using the device and didn't lose much. To do a factory reset hold down the power button and the up (not the down) volume button from the off state. The down button will take you into some weird Chinese menu used for product testing or something.

The sound quality, speed, and graphics aren't the best, but for $100 it's fair.

Purchased this tablet for my 8 year old son.  He was up and running after a few minutes, everything connected and worked great right out of the box.  Seems to be well made and pretty fast for the price point.  So far we are very happy with this tablet and hope it lasts.
